scenesList.scene_2: Welcome to the Golden Age of Baghdad

start.title:
Al-Khwarizmi's Merchant Mathematics Quest

From Chaos to Wisdom
start.description: Can you help Al-Khwarizmi transform a struggling merchant's business using the power of mathematics? In this STEAMQuest, you'll journey through 9th century Baghdad, applying algebraic thinking, balance principles, and risk analysis to solve real-world trading problems. Discover how systematic mathematical reasoning can turn business chaos into profitable wisdom!

S2_D1_F4_C0.heading: Welcome to the Golden Age of Baghdad
S2_D1_F4_C0.body: The bustling markets of 9th century Baghdad hum with activity as merchants from across the known world gather to trade precious goods. The scent of dates, spices, and incense fills the air, while the sound of haggling voices echoes through the narrow streets. In this era of the Islamic Golden Age, mathematical knowledge flourishes alongside commerce.

S3.S3_D1_F5_C0: In 9th century Baghdad, modern day Iraq, one man changed everything.

S4.S4_D1_F6_C0: Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi discovered that merchant trades, architectural designs, and tax calculations are secretly the same problem in disguise.
S4.S4_D2_F7_C0: While others memorized hundreds of different tricks, Al-Khwarizmi saw one hidden pattern connecting them all.

S5.S5_D1_F8_C0: He called his method 'Al Jabr' - find any unknown by keeping both sides balanced.
S5.S5_D2_F9_C0: So powerful was this idea that 1,200 years later, we still call it by his name: algebra.
S5.S5_D3_F10_C0: He didn't just solve problems. He taught the world a new way to think.

S6.S6_D1_F11_C0: Today, he's about to share that power with someone who desperately needs it...

S7.S7_D2_F13_C1: Wa aleikum salaam my friend, you look distressed, how can I help you?
S7.S7_D3_F14_C2: You see well my friend, my date trading business is failing, and I cannot understand why! I work from dawn to dusk, I sell dates every day, yet somehow I'm losing money.
S7.S7_D4_F15_C1: Ah, another soul wrestling with the same mystery I encounter daily. Show me your records, my friend, I suspect the answer lies hidden in plain sight.

S8_D0_F16_C9.title: Tariq's Ledger of Sales
S8_D0_F16_C9.ledger_aria_label: Table showing merchant transactions with amounts in dirhams and transaction descriptions

S8.S8_D1_F16_C2: Here they are... all of them! I write down every transaction, but nothing makes sense! Look—here's 12 dirhams from selling dates, here's 20 dirhams for warehouse rent, here's 20 dirhams from another sale...
S8.S8_D2_F17_C1: You have gathered all the pieces of the puzzle. Your dedication is clear, but these numbers are like guests at a feast without proper seating—each valuable, but needing their rightful place to serve their purpose.
S8.S8_D3_F18_C2: You speak too wise for me, great Al-Khwarizmi. I've tried everything, you can help me make sense of this chaos!
S8.S8_D4_F19_C1: Come, let us honor these numbers by giving each its proper home. Three simple groups will reveal the wisdom your hard work has already collected, with these categories you will see the patterns.
S8.S8_D5_F20_C1: Help me sort these ledger entries into their proper categories. Each entry tells part of your business story, but only when organized can we see the complete picture.
S8.S8_D6_F21_C2: I... I never thought to organize them that way. How do I know which category each entry belongs to?
S8.S8_D7_F22_C1: Revenue is the money we earn, variable costs are costs that change with the moon, fixed costs you have to pay regardless of how much you sell, for example rent.

S9_D0_F23_C9.title: Date Merchant Ledger Explorer

help.heading: How to Organize the Merchant's Ledger
help.body:
1. Examine Each Entry:
    Look at both the amount and the description for each transaction.
  2. Identify Revenue:
    Drag entries showing money earned from selling dates to the Revenue category
  3. Identify Fixed Costs:
    Move expenses that stay the same each month (like rent, equipment) to Fixed Costs
  4. Identify Variable Costs:
    Place costs that change with business activity (materials, transport) in Variable Costs

Classification Tips:

  • Revenue entries typically say 'sold,' 'earned,' or 'received'
  • Fixed costs include rent, salaries, equipment - things you pay regardless of sales volume
  • Variable costs include materials, transportation, commissions - things that increase with more sales
  • When unsure, ask: 'Does this cost change if I sell more or fewer dates?'

info.heading: Business Transaction Categorization Principles
info.body:
1. Revenue Recognition:
    Revenue represents all money earned from business activities - the income flowing into your business.
  2. Fixed Costs:
    These are expenses that remain constant regardless of business volume (rent, salaries, equipment costs).
  3. Variable Costs:
    These are expenses that change based on business activity levels (materials, transportation, commission fees).
  4. Profit Analysis:
    The fundamental equation: Profit = Revenue - (Fixed Costs + Variable Costs)

In this interactive, you will:

  • Sort chaotic ledger entries into their proper business categories
  • Discover hidden patterns in seemingly random financial data
  • Calculate total revenue, fixed costs, and variable costs
  • Reveal why the merchant's business is losing money through systematic organization

Mathematical Organization Properties

  • Categories must be mutually exclusive (each entry belongs to only one category)
  • The sum of all categorized entries equals the original total
  • Clear categorization reveals relationships hidden in unorganized data

S9_D0_F23_C9.date_merchant_ledger_explorer: Date Merchant Ledger Explorer - Interactive Categorization Game

S9_D0_F23_C9.two_methods_description: You can use two methods: 1) Drag and drop entries between sections, or 2) Click or press Enter on any entry to reveal category buttons, then use those buttons to move entries.
S9_D0_F23_C9.check_understanding_instruction: When you're finished categorizing all entries, activate the Check Understanding button to verify your answers.

S9_D0_F23_C9.no_items_category_yet: No items in this category yet
S9_D0_F23_C9.check_understanding_verify: Check Understanding - Verify if all ledger entries are correctly categorized

S9.S9_D1_F23_C1: Drag each ledger entry to its correct category. Look at each transaction and ask yourself: "Is this money coming in, a cost that stays the same, or a cost that changes with my business?"
S9.S9_D2_F24_C1: Outstanding! Now we can see your business clearly. What do you notice about these organized numbers?
S9.S9_D3_F25_C2: I earned 60 dirhams in revenue, but my costs total 100 dirhams!
S9.S9_D4_F26_C1: Precisely! You're losing 40 dirhams because your costs exceed your income. This is why organization is the foundation of all wisdom—it reveals truths hidden in chaos.

S10.S10_D1_F27_C1: Do not lose hope my friend, why don't you bring me a scale?
S10.S10_D2_F28_C2: My old scale? You are so wise yet I do not understand, how can weighing dates help with mathematics?
S10.S10_D3_F29_C1: Mathematics is everywhere, my friend. We already know you need to make 40 dirhams. Watch how this simple tool reveals profound truths, where are the dates you want to sell?
S10.S10_D4_F30_C2: I have 8 dates here, and I want 40 dirhams for them. But I don't know what to charge for each one.
S10.S10_D5_F31_C1:
Perfect! We'll use the scale to discover the answer. Think of it as asking a question:
If 8 dates equal 40 dirhams, what does 1 date equal?
S10.S10_D6_F32_C1: The scale teaches us about balance—and balance is the heart of all equations. On one side, we place what you have. On the other, what you want.

S11_D0_F33_C9.title: Balance Scale Activity

help.heading: How to Use the Balance Scale
help.body:
1. Set Up the Problem:
    Place what you have (8 dates) on the left side of the scale
  2. Balance It:
    Place what you want (40 dirhams) on the right side to achieve balance
  3. Apply Halving Method:
    • Remove half the dates from the left side
    • Remove half the coins from the right side to restore balance
  4. Repeat Until Solved:
    Continue halving both sides until you have 1 date on the left
  5. Read the Answer:
    The remaining coins on the right show the price per date

Key Rules:

  • The scale tips when unbalanced - this shows you need to adjust the other side
  • Always remove the same proportion from both sides
  • Stop when you reach 1 date = Some dirhams

info.heading: Mathematical Balance Principles
info.body:
The key properties demonstrated in this interactive:

  1. Physical Balance:
    A scale remains balanced when both sides have equal weight or value.
  2. Proportional Reasoning:
    If 8 dates equal 40 dirhams, then the ratio can be simplified to find the price per date.
  3. Halving Method:
    Removing half from both sides maintains balance while simplifying the problem.
  4. Algebraic Foundation:
    Physical balance demonstrates the fundamental principle that equations must remain equal on both sides.

In this interactive, you will:

  • Use a physical balance scale to solve pricing problems
  • Apply the halving method to reduce complex ratios to simple ones
  • Discover that 8 dates worth 40 dirhams means 1 date costs 5 dirhams
  • Experience the physical foundation of algebraic equation solving

Balance Scale Properties

When using scales for mathematical reasoning:

  • Whatever operation you perform on one side must be performed on the other
  • The goal is to isolate one unit (1 date) to find its individual value
  • Each halving step brings you closer to the unit price

S11_D0_F33_C9.remove_half_dates_left_side: Remove half the dates from the left side of the scale
S11_D0_F33_C9.remove_half_dirhams_right_side: Remove half the dirhams from the right side of the scale
S11_D0_F33_C9.excellent_see_scale_tips: Excellent! See how the scale tips?
S11_D0_F33_C9.now_need_balance: Now we need something to balance it.
S11_D0_F33_C9.scale_tips_toward_coins: The scale tips toward the coins.
S11_D0_F33_C9.scale_revealed_truth: The scale has revealed the truth!
S11_D0_F33_C9.al_khwarizmi_place_current_left: Al-Khwarizmi: Place what you currently have on the left side of the scale.
S11_D0_F33_C9.al_khwarizmi_place_want_right: Al-Khwarizmi: Now place what you want to receive on the right side.
S11_D0_F33_C9.al_khwarizmi_secret_remove_half_dates: Al-Khwarizmi: Now for the secret: remove half the dates from the left side.
S11_D0_F33_C9.al_khwarizmi_precisely_remove_half_coins: Al-Khwarizmi: Precisely! Whatever we do to one side, we must do to the other. Remove half the coins to restore balance.
S11_D0_F33_C9.al_khwarizmi_wonderful_balance_restored: Al-Khwarizmi: Wonderful! The balance is restored.
S11_D0_F33_C9.al_khwarizmi_closer_remove_half_dates_ag: Al-Khwarizmi: We're getting closer to our answer. Take away half the dates again.
S11_D0_F33_C9.al_khwarizmi_now_half_coins_balance: Al-Khwarizmi: And now half the coins to balance it once more.
S11_D0_F33_C9.dirhams_power_balance: dirhams! This is the power of mathematical balance.
S11_D0_F33_C9.scale_revealed_answer: The scale has revealed the answer: 1 date =

S11.S11_D1_F33_C1: You currently have dates, but you want to get money from them. Why don't you put what we have, on the left side of the scale!
S11.S11_D2_F34_C1: Now place what you want to receive on the right side of the scale.
S11.S11_D3_F35_C1: Very good! Now we have perfectly balanced what we want, with what we have. But you want to know how much you should sell one date for, now we only know what to sell 8 dates for.
S11.S11_D4_F36_C1: Why don't you take away half the dates?
S11.S11_D5_F37_C2: But now it isn't balanced anymore!
S11.S11_D6_F38_C1: Exactly! It is too much money for just the four dates that are left, so the scale tips toward the coins. To restore balance we must also remove half of the coins, why don't you try it?
S11.S11_D7_F39_C2: They are balanced again!
S11.S11_D8_F40_C1: Precisely! Whatever we do to one side, we must do to the other as well to keep the natural balance.
S11.S11_D9_F41_C2: Yet we still do not know what I should sell one date for…
S11.S11_D10_F42_C1: Well, let's repeat it and remove half the dates.
S11.S11_D11_F43_C1: You can once again see it is out of balance, you know what to do!
S11.S11_D12_F44_C1: Keep going until you know how much one date costs.

S12.S12_D1_F45_C1: The scale has revealed the truth! This is the power of mathematical balance, whatever we do to one side, we must do to the other. We know now we need to ask 5 dirhams for one date.
S12.S12_D2_F46_C2: This is remarkable! But I forgot to tell you, I also need some dates for myself to bring to the mosque, so this will not work…
S12.S12_D3_F47_C1: Do not worry my friend! The principle for this problem remains the same, but we'll need to handle the dates that appear on both sides more carefully.

S13_D0_F48_C9.title: Complex Balance Scale Activity

help.heading: How to Solve Complex Balance Problems
help.body:
1. Initial Setup:
    Place all 10 dates on the left side
  2. Right Side Setup:
    Place both the 2 dates you're keeping for family AND the 60 dirhams you want to earn on the right side
  3. Eliminate Like Terms:
    • Remove the 2 dates from the right side (your family reserve)
    • Remove 2 dates from the left side to maintain balance
  4. Apply Standard Method:
    Now use the halving technique on the remaining 8 dates and 60 dirhams
  5. Continue Until Solved:
    Keep halving until you have 1 date = Some dirhams

Why This Works:

  • Removing equal amounts from both sides maintains the mathematical relationship
  • The higher price (7.5 dirhams vs. 5 dirhams) reflects the smaller quantity available for sale
  • Personal reserves create a constraint that affects business pricing

info.heading: Multi-Variable Balance Principles
info.body:
The key properties demonstrated in this interactive:

  1. Complex Equations:
    When the same item appears on both sides, special techniques are needed to solve the problem.
  2. Elimination Method:
    Remove identical items from both sides before applying standard solving techniques.
  3. Real-World Constraints:
    Business problems often involve reserving some resources for personal use.
  4. Higher Unit Pricing:
    When you sell fewer items due to personal reserves, the remaining items must be priced higher to meet profit goals.

In this interactive, you will:

  • Handle equations where dates appear on both sides of the balance
  • Learn to eliminate terms before solving
  • Discover why reserved inventory increases the unit price of remaining items
  • Master the technique of removing like terms from both sides

Complex Balance Properties

When solving equations with variables on both sides:

  • First eliminate the variable from one side by subtracting equal amounts
  • Then apply standard solving techniques to the simplified equation
  • The solution accounts for the constraint of reserved inventory

S13_D0_F48_C9.remove_half_dates_aria: Remove half the dates from left side
S13_D0_F48_C9.remove_half_coins_aria: Remove half the coins from right side

S13_D0_F48_C9.al_khwarizmi_step1: Put the total of all your dates—all 10 of them—on the left side of the scale.
S13_D0_F48_C9.al_khwarizmi_step2: On the right side, place both the dates you're keeping for the family and the coins you want to earn.
S13_D0_F48_C9.al_khwarizmi_step3: Now we face a challenge—we have dates on both sides. Before we can start our halving process, we must remove the dates from the right side.
S13_D0_F48_C9.al_khwarizmi_step3_why: Because we need to isolate what we're selling from what we're keeping, we have to remember the ledger! Let's remove the 2 dates we keep for ourselves.
S13_D0_F48_C9.merchant_step4_unbalanced: We've disturbed the balance Al-Khwarizmi! Can we divide the other side by half?
S13_D0_F48_C9.al_khwarizmi_step4_response: To restore balance, we cannot do so. We took away two, not half. Whatever we do to one side, we must do to the other. Try removing 2 dates from the left!
S13_D0_F48_C9.al_khwarizmi_step5_perfect: Perfect! Now we have 8 dates on the left, 60 dirhams on the right, and perfect balance. Now we can continue with our method just like earlier. Let's keep removing half and half, until the scale is balanced and we have only one date on the left!
S13_D0_F48_C9.merchant_final: There! One date equals 7.5 dirhams, which is more than before!
S13_D0_F48_C9.al_khwarizmi_final: The balance scale reveals mathematical truth, you have the same costs, but now you can sell fewer dates. And so because you keep some of the dates, the rest you have to sell for more!
S13_D0_F48_C9.step1_success: Good! Now we place what you want on the right side.
S13_D0_F48_C9.step1_error: Wrong number of dates. Remember, you have 10 dates in total to start with.
S13_D0_F48_C9.step2_success: Excellent! The scale shows your complete situation now.
S13_D0_F48_C9.step2_error: Missing items. You need both the 2 dates for family AND the 60 dirhams on the right side.
S13_D0_F48_C9.step3_success: Good! Now the scale is unbalanced. We need to fix this.
S13_D0_F48_C9.step4_success: Perfect! Balance restored. Now we can proceed with halving.
S13_D0_F48_C9.step5_success: Wonderful! Each date is now worth 7.5 dirhams.
S13_D0_F48_C9.scale_tips_toward_coins: The scale tips toward the coins.
S13_D0_F48_C9.scale_revealed_truth: The scale has revealed the truth.

S13.S13_D1_F48_C1: Put the total of all your dates—all 10 of them—on the left side of the scale.
S13.S13_D2_F49_C1: On the right side, place both the dates you're keeping for the family and the coins you want to earn.
S13.S13_D3_F50_C1: Now we face a challenge—we have dates on both sides. Before we can start our halving process, we must remove the dates from the right side.
S13.S13_D5_F52_C1: Because we need to isolate what we're selling from what we're keeping, we have to remember the ledger! Let's remove the 2 dates we keep for ourselves.
S13.S13_D6_F53_C2: We've disturbed the balance Al Khwarizmi! Can we divide the other side by half?
S13.S13_D7_F54_C1: To restore balance, we cannot do so. We took away two, not half.
S13.S13_D8_F55_C2: So I remove 2 dates from the left as well?
S13.S13_D9_F56_C1: Exactly! Whatever we do to one side, we must do to the other. Try it!
S13.S13_D10_F57_C1: Perfect! Now we have 8 dates on the left, 60 dirhams on the right, and perfect balance.
S13.S13_D11_F58_C1: Now we can continue with our method just like earlier. Lets keep removing half and half, until the scale is balanced and we have only one date on the left!
S13.S13_D12_F59_C2: There! One date equals 7.5 dirhams, which is more than before!
S13.S13_D13_F60_C1: The balance scale reveals mathematical truth, you have the same costs, but now you can sell less dates.
S13.S13_D14_F61_C2: And so because I keep some of the dates, the rest I have to sell for more!

S14.S14_D1_F62_C2: This is all great, but moving all these dates and coins becomes tiresome. I cannot do this everyday…
S14.S14_D2_F63_C1: I understand my friend. Let me show you a much faster way using symbols and numbers alone
S14.S14_D3_F64_C2: Faster than the scale?
S14.S14_D4_F65_C1: Much faster! Instead of moving physical objects, we will use symbols to represent them.

S15.S15_D1_F67_C0: Al-Khwarizmi works at the House of Wisdom: the world's first international research center, where the greatest minds collaborate regardless of religion or nationality.
S15.S15_D2_F68_C0: While European scholars hoard knowledge in isolation, Baghdad brings together Greek mathematicians, Indian astronomers, Persian philosophers, and Arab translators under one roof.

S16.S16_D1_F69_C0: Here, Al-Khwarizmi doesn't just read old books, he combines Indian numerals with Greek geometry and Persian algebra to invent entirely new mathematics.
S16.S16_D2_F70_C0: The House of Wisdom is where humanity's scattered knowledge becomes unified power, and Al-Khwarizmi is its leading scholar.

S17.S17_D1_F71_C0: In this very room, surrounded by the wisdom of ages, Al-Khwarizmi transforms individual problems into universal solutions that will echo through history.

S18.S18_D1_F72_C1: We always want to know the unknown, that is the point of algebra. In your situation, we want to know how much to sell a date for.
S18.S18_D2_F73_C1:
We'll call one date 'x'.
So 5 dates becomes '5x', and 10 dates become '10x'.
S18.S18_D3_F74_C2: That's... clever. But how do we solve it without the scale?
S18.S18_D4_F75_C1: The same way! We still balance both sides, but now we use division instead of physically removing objects.

S19_D0_F76_C9.title: From Physical to Mathematical

help.heading: How to Build and Solve Algebraic Equations
help.body:
1. Build the Equation:
    Drag numbers and symbols to create the equation representing your problem
    • Left side: number of dates * x (like 5x)
    • Right side: total money wanted (like 25)
  2. Choose the Divisor:
    Determine what number to divide by (hint: use the coefficient of x)
  3. Divide Left Side:
    Perform the division on the left side (5x ÷ 5 = x)
  4. Divide Right Side:
    Apply the same division to the right side to maintain balance
  5. Read the Solution:
    The result shows x = [price per date]

Mathematical Rules:

  • Always perform the same operation on both sides
  • Choose your divisor to eliminate the coefficient of x
  • The goal is to isolate x on one side of the equation

info.heading: Algebraic Translation Principles
info.body:
The key properties demonstrated in this interactive:

  1. Symbol Representation:
    Variables (like x) represent unknown quantities, making problems more efficient to solve.
  2. Equation Structure:
    The equals sign functions like a balance scale - both sides must remain equal.
  3. Division Method:
    Instead of physically removing objects, division achieves the same mathematical result.
  4. Abstraction Power:
    Mathematical symbols allow faster problem-solving than physical manipulation.

In this interactive, you will:

  • Transform physical scale problems into algebraic equations
  • Use x to represent the unknown price per date
  • Apply division instead of the physical halving method
  • Experience the transition from concrete to abstract mathematical thinking

Algebraic Equation Properties

When working with equations:

  • The variable (x) represents what you're trying to find
  • Coefficients (like the 5 in 5x) show how many units you have
  • Division isolates the variable by removing coefficients
  • The same operation must be applied to both sides

S19_D0_F76_C9.final_scale_description: Balance scale is now perfectly balanced, showing 1 date on the left plate and 5 coins on the right plate, demonstrating that x equals 5.
S19_D0_F76_C9.equation_solved_explanation: The equation has been solved. X equals 5. This means each date is worth 5 coins.

S19_D0_F76_C9.right_division_success: Perfect! You've correctly balanced both sides of the equation.
S19_D0_F76_C9.dates_fraction: dates, which is a fraction. We need a whole number of dates.
S19_D0_F76_C9.no_whole_number: doesn't give us a whole number of dates. Try another value.
S19_D0_F76_C9.remember_one_date: Remember, we have 1 date on the left side.
S19_D0_F76_C9.create_valid_equation: Please create a valid equation with the values before proceeding.
S19_D0_F76_C9.divide_left_correctly: Please divide the left side by the correct value to get exactly 1 date.
S19_D0_F76_C9.divide_right_correctly: Please divide the right side by the correct value to balance the equation.
S19_D0_F76_C9.dirhams_for_them: dirhams for them. Fill in the blanks to create the equation.
S19_D0_F76_C9.step1_instruction2: Drag the values from below to the empty placeholders to create a valid equation.
S19_D0_F76_C9.step2_instruction1: We need to find out the value of one date.
S19_D0_F76_C9.step2_instruction2: We can't just divide by 2, that would give us a fraction value.
S19_D0_F76_C9.step2_instruction3: What should we divide by so that we get a whole number?
S19_D0_F76_C9.step3_instruction1: See the scale is imbalanced now. Please perform the same operation on the right side too.
S19_D0_F76_C9.step3_instruction2: We've divided the left side by 5, now divide the right side to restore balance.
S19_D0_F76_C9.step4_instruction: Perfect! The equation is now solved and the scale is balanced.
S19_D0_F76_C9.lets_solve_step_by_step: Let's solve this step by step.
S19_D0_F76_C9.restart_entire_activity: Restart the entire activity from step 1
S19_D0_F76_C9.complete_equation_to_proceed: Complete the equation to proceed to the next step.
S19_D0_F76_C9.divide_left_correctly_to_proceed: Divide the left side correctly to proceed.
S19_D0_F76_C9.divide_right_correctly_to_finish: Divide the right side correctly to finish.
S19_D0_F76_C9.enforcing_correct_value: After two attempts, setting the correct value of 5 to help you proceed.

S19.S19_D1_F76_C1: The equal sign functions as a conceptual scale, what is on both sides must always stay balanced.
S19.S19_D2_F77_C1: If you have 5 dates and want 25 dirhams, help me create the equation. Drag the numbers and symbols to build it, just like you would have on the scale.
S19.S19_D3_F78_C1: Perfect! Now, instead of taking away half, we can divide. But we must be smart about our choice.
S19.S19_D4_F79_C2: What do you mean?
S19.S19_D5_F80_C1: If we divide by 2, we get fractions—2.5x equals 12.5 dirhams. Fractions are difficult for commerce.
S19.S19_D6_F81_C2: Then what should we divide by?
S19.S19_D7_F82_C1: Think about it, if we have 5x, how many times did we do x?
S19.S19_D8_F83_C1: What number should we divide both sides by to avoid fractions?
S19.S19_D9_F84_C1: Just like taking away half, now we divide not by 2, but by 5!
S19.S19_D10_F85_C1: Now divide the left side: 5x ÷ 5.
S19.S19_D11_F86_C2: Al Khwarizmi, we have now disturbed the balance after dividing by 5 on the Left side…
S19.S19_D12_F87_C1: You have noticed well my friend, to keep the scale balanced we must perform the same division on the Right side!
S19.S19_D13_F88_C1: Now divide the right side: 25 ÷ 5.
S19.S19_D14_F89_C1: There! x = 5. One date costs 5 dirhams, solved without moving a single physical object!
S19.S19_D15_F90_C2: This is like magic, but with numbers!
S19.S19_D16_F91_C1: It's not magic, it is what I call Al Jabr. The same principles as the scale, but much more efficient.
S19.S19_D17_F92_C2: Can this method solve even bigger problems?
S19.S19_D18_F93_C1: It can! Let me show you how we can use this to maximize your profits across different markets.

S20.S20_D2_F95_C1: A caravan master says Damascus pays 18 dirhams per pound for dates, versus our 10 dirhams here. But transport costs 2 dirhams per pound.
S20.S20_D3_F96_C2: So in Damascus I can make 6 dirhams more per pound? Should I send everything there?
S20.S20_D4_F97_C1: Let's use mathematics to be certain. If you have 100 pounds total, we need to ask ourselves how to divide them to maximize profit.
S20.S20_D5_F98_C2: Mathematics can solve that?
S20.S20_D6_F99_C1: Most definitely! We will build simple equations to find your optimal strategy.

S21_D0_F100_C9.title: Profit Optimization - Two Markets

help.heading: How to Build Profit Optimization Functions
help.body:
1. Baghdad Profit:
    Create the expression for local sales (10x pounds)
  2. Determine Damascus Quantity:
    If you have 100 pounds total and sell x locally, Damascus gets (100-x) pounds
  3. Calculate Damascus Net Profit:
    Subtract transport costs from Damascus selling price (18-2 = 16 dirhams per pound)
  4. Damascus Profit Function:
    Build the expression 16(100-x)
  5. Combine Functions:
    Add Baghdad and Damascus profits together
  6. Simplify Expression:
    • Expand: 16(100-x) = 1600 - 16x
    • Combine: 10x + 1600 - 16x = 1600 - 6x
  7. Interpret Results:
    The negative coefficient of x shows that local sales reduce total profit

Key Insights:

  • Maximum profit (1600) occurs when x = 0 (send everything to Damascus)
  • Each local sale costs 6 dirhams in lost profit
  • The function guides optimal allocation decisions

info.heading: Multi-Market Optimization Principles
info.body:
The key properties demonstrated in this interactive:

  1. Profit Functions:
    Mathematical expressions that show how profit changes based on allocation decisions.
  2. Market Comparison:
    Different markets offer different profit margins that must be weighed against constraints.
  3. Variable Interdependence:
    When total inventory is fixed, selling more in one market means selling less in another.
  4. Linear Optimization:
    The final profit function reveals whether to favor one market over another.

In this interactive, you will:

  • Build separate profit functions for Baghdad and Damascus markets
  • Combine individual market functions into a total profit equation
  • Simplify complex expressions to reveal optimization insights

Optimization Function Properties

When modeling business decisions:

  • Each market has its own profit-per-unit calculation
  • Total inventory creates a constraint linking both markets
  • The simplified function reveals the optimal allocation strategy
  • Negative coefficients indicate opportunity costs

S21_D0_F100_C9.baghdad_profit_success: Correct! This represents the profit from Baghdad sales.
S21_D0_F100_C9.baghdad_profit_error: Not quite. Remember: Profit = Price per pound × Pounds sold

S21_D0_F100_C9.damascus_profit_success: Correct! This represents the profit from Damascus sales.
S21_D0_F100_C9.damascus_profit_error: Not quite. Remember: Profit = Price per pound × Pounds sold
S21_D0_F100_C9.total_profit_success: Correct! This represents the total profit function.
S21_D0_F100_C9.total_profit_error: Not quite. Remember to combine both profit formulas.
S21_D0_F100_C9.expansion_success: Correct! The equation is properly expanded.
S21_D0_F100_C9.expansion_error: Not quite. Remember to distribute the multiplication.
S21_D0_F100_C9.simplification_success: Correct! The terms are properly combined.
S21_D0_F100_C9.simplification_error: Not quite. Remember to combine like terms.
S21_D0_F100_C9.build_baghdad_profit: Build the profit formula for Baghdad
S21_D0_F100_C9.build_damascus_profit: Build the profit formula for Damascus
S21_D0_F100_C9.complete_step_error: Please complete the current step before proceeding

S21.S21_D1_F100_C1: Let's say you sell x pounds in Baghdad at 10 dirhams per pound. What's your Baghdad profit?
S21.S21_D2_F101_C2: The Baghdad profit would be 10x, or 10 dirhams for each pound of dates sold.
S21.S21_D3_F102_C1: Now tell me one thing. If you have 100 pounds total and sell x pounds in Baghdad, how many pounds go to Damascus?
S21.S21_D4_F103_C1: Very well! If we sell x pounds in Baghdad, then remaining pounds will go to Damascus. So, the answer to that would be 100 - x.
S21.S21_D5_F104_C1: We know that we can sell these dates in Damascus at 18 dirhams per pound. And it costs us 2 dirhams per pound to send these dates.
S21.S21_D6_F105_C1: How much profit can we make in Damascus per pound?
S21.S21_D7_F106_C1: Profit can be calculated just like in Baghdad: How many pounds you are selling times the price of that pound. My friend, can you now find the formula for the potential profit in Damascus?
S21.S21_D8_F107_C2: I can see we now have both the profit in Damascus as well as in Baghdad, but I still see a lot of x. What do I do with this?
S21.S21_D9_F108_C1: We need to combine both profits together. Because we said x is the same in both equations, we can just add them together! What's your total profit from both markets?
S21.S21_D10_F109_C1: Let's simplify this expression. First, what does 16(100-x) equal when expanded?
S21.S21_D11_F110_C1: Now we combine everything: 10x + 1600 - 16x. What's the simplified form?
S21.S21_D12_F111_C2: I understand the simplification, but now what have we actually done?
S21.S21_D13_F112_C1: Look at this equation carefully: P(x) = 1600 - 6x. It shows us x (pounds sold in Baghdad), and our Profit.
S21.S21_D14_F113_C1: What does the 1600 mean here?
S21.S21_D14_F113_C9_optionC: Profit we always make regardless of how much we sell.
S21.S21_D15_F114_C2: I see! Because after the 1600 there is a minus, so we can only go down…
S21.S21_D16_F115_C1: Exactly! You are analyzing the formula correctly. Lets analyze our profit now.
S21.S21_D17_F116_C1: If we sell one more pound in Baghdad, our x goes up by one, meaning?
S21.S21_D18_F117_C2: So if we sell more pounds in Baghdad, x goes up, meaning our profit goes down!
S21.S21_D19_F118_C1: Exactly! You lose 6 dirhams profit for every pound sold locally instead of in Damascus.
S21.S21_D20_F119_C2: So should I send everything to Damascus?
S21.S21_D21_F120_C1: Mathematically, yes! You'd earn the maximum profit of 1600 dirhams by setting x = 0.
S21.S21_D22_F121_C2: This is incredible! Mathematics shows me the perfect business strategy.
S21.S21_D23_F122_C1: Indeed! But now you face a new challenge. If you organize such expeditions, you'll need partners.

S22.S22_D1_F122_C0: The route to Damascus follows the ancient Silk Road - the legendary network connecting East and West for over a thousand years.
S22.S22_D2_F123_C0: Here, camel caravans carry the world's most precious goods: silk from China, spices from India, and dates from Baghdad's markets.

S23.S23_D1_F124_C0: Across these desert paths flows the world's first global economy, creating unimaginable wealth for those brave enough to risk the journey.
S23.S23_D2_F125_C0: But the Silk Road's riches come with equal dangers, and Al-Khwarizmi knows that mathematical perfection must meet harsh desert realities.

S24.S24_D1_F126_C0: Sandstorms can bury entire caravans, bandits lurk at remote oases, and political conflicts can close routes overnight.
S24.S24_D2_F127_C0: Where a single miscalculation can mean financial ruin, success depends not just on mathematics, but on choosing the right partners and sharing profits fairly.

S25.S25_D1_F128_C0: This is why Al-Khwarizmi's next lesson will be his most crucial - teaching the merchant how to organize profitable expeditions by fairly dividing rewards among the caravan master, lead merchant, and himself.

S26.S26_D1_F129_C1: Tell me, if you send everything to Damascus, who will organize this great expedition?
S26.S26_D2_F130_C2: I... I hadn't thought about that. I suppose I do need partners.
S26.S26_D3_F131_C1: You do. First, you need a Caravan Master - someone who knows the desert routes, can navigate by stars, and manage the camels and supplies.
S26.S26_D4_F132_C2: That makes sense. The desert is dangerous.
S26.S26_D5_F133_C1: Second, you need a Lead Merchant - someone who knows Damascus markets, speaks their dialect, and can negotiate the best prices there.
S26.S26_D6_F134_C1: Third is you, my friend - the one who provides the capital, takes the financial risk, and organizes this entire venture.
S26.S26_D7_F135_C2: And so how do I divide the profits fairly?
S26.S26_D8_F136_C1: An excellent question! This is where mathematics becomes even more powerful. We must account for different contributions and risks. Workers get fixed wages, but you three have more responsibility and therefore share the profits. First, we calculate the profit after paying all workers.
S26.S26_D9_F137_C1: How is this profit calculated?
S26.S26_D10_F138_C1: Exactly! Whatever we do not have to pay to others is left to divide among those leading the expedition.

S27_D0_FX_C9.title: Risk Management - Uncertainty and Demand

help.heading: How to Solve Partnership Profit Distribution Systems
help.body:
Step 1 - Set Up Variables:

  • Let M = Merchant's share (you, the funding partner)
  • Let L = Lead Merchant's share (Damascus market specialist)
  • Let C = Caravan Master's share (desert expedition leader)

Step 2 - Build the System:

  • Total Distribution: M + L + C = 4500 (all profit must be divided)
  • Risk Premium: M = 2C (funding partner gets double the caravan master)
  • Expertise Bonus: L = C + 500 (market specialist gets 500 more than caravan master)

Step 3 - Identify Substitution Strategy:

  • Look for variables already expressed in terms of others
  • Both M and L are given in terms of C, making C the key variable
  • Substitute the expressions for M and L into the total distribution equation

Step 4 - Systematic Substitution:

  • Replace M with 2C in the first equation: 2C + L + C = 4500
  • Replace L with (C + 500): 2C + (C + 500) + C = 4500
  • Combine like terms: 4C + 500 = 4500
  • Solve for C: 4C = 4000, so C = 1000

Step 5 - Calculate Remaining Variables:

  • Use C = 1000 to find L = C + 500 = 1500
  • Use C = 1000 to find M = 2C = 2000
  • Verify: 2000 + 1500 + 1000 = 4500

Partnership Principles:

  • The funding partner bears the greatest financial risk and receives the largest share
  • Specialists with unique skills (market knowledge) receive premium compensation
  • All partners contribute essential capabilities that justify their profit participation
  • Mathematical precision ensures fair and transparent profit distribution

info.heading: Multi-Variable System Principles
info.body:
The key properties demonstrated in this interactive:

  1. Multiple Variables:
    When dividing profits among partners, each person's share is an unknown that must be determined simultaneously with the others.
  2. System Solutions:
    Multiple equations with multiple unknowns require systematic substitution to find the unique solution where all conditions are met.
  3. Substitution Method:
    Express variables in terms of one another, then substitute to reduce a complex system to a single equation with one variable.
  4. Precise Calculation:
    Mathematical systems eliminate guesswork and ensure that complex profit-sharing calculations are exact and verifiable.

In this interactive, you will:

  • Build equations representing profit-sharing relationships among three expedition partners
  • Learn to identify which variable to solve for first in a system
  • Use substitution to systematically reduce three equations to one solvable equation
  • Verify that your solution satisfies original partnership agreements

System Properties

When working with systems of equations:

  • Each equation represents a separate business relationship or constraint
  • The number of equations needed equals the number of unknown variables
  • Substitution reduces complexity by eliminating variables one at a time
  • The solution must satisfy every equation in the system simultaneously

S27_D0_FX_C9.yes_what_amount: Yes! What amount would that be?

S27.S27_D11_F139_C1: Lets say there is 4500 dirhams profit. We must divide these 4500 dirhams fairly among the three partners. Each person gets a share of the total profit.
S27.S27_D12_F140_C1: If you get M dirhams, the Lead Merchant gets L dirhams, and the Caravan Master gets C dirhams, and we must distribute ALL the profit, help me write this as an equation.
S27.S27_D13_F141_C1: Perfect! This equation shows that all three shares must add up to the total profit.
S27.S27_D14_F142_C1: This equation has many variables. How many variables can be solved with a single equation?
S27.S27_D15_F143_C1: Correct! But how many variables do we have in this first equation?
S27.S27_D16_F144_C1: So can we solve with this equation alone?
S27.S27_D17_F145_C1: To solve for three variables, how many equations do we need minimally?
S27.S27_D18_F146_C1: Exactly! So we need two more equations. Luckily we know more about the division of profit.
S27.S27_D19_F147_C1: You, as the funding party of the expedition, should get at least 2 times as much as the caravan master leading it.
S27.S27_D20_F148_C1: Excellent! You take the greatest financial risk, so you receive the largest share.
S27.S27_D21_F149_C1: One final relationship. The Lead Merchant should get more than the Caravan Master because he needs specialized knowledge of Damascus markets.
S27.S27_D22_F150_C1: If we want to give him 500 dirhams more than the Caravan Master, what should the equation look like?
S27.S27_D23_F151_C1: Perfect! Now we have three equations with three unknowns.
S27.S27_D24_F152_C1: We now have three equations. The one that includes all three variables is which equation?
S27.S27_D25_F153_C2: The first one : M + L + C = 4500.
S27.S27_D26_F154_C1: In this first equation, we want to create an equation with just one variable instead of three. This means we have to substitute two variables.
S27.S27_D27_F155_C1: Look at the other equations! Which two variables are already given in terms of others?
S27.S27_D27_F155_C1_optionA: L and M, both given in values of C
S27.S27_D27_F155_C1_optionB: L and C, both given in values of M
S27.S27_D27_F155_C1_optionC: M and C, both given in values of L
S27.S27_D28_F156_C1: Exactly! L = C + 500, and M = 2C. Both depend on C.
S27.S27_D29_F157_C1: Now we substitute. If M = 2C, let's replace M in our first equation.
S27.S27_D30_F158_C1: Good! Now we have 2C + L + C = 4500.
S27.S27_D31_F159_C1: Now substitute L = C + 500 into our equation.
S27.S27_D32_F160_C1: Excellent! Now we have 2C + (C + 500) + C = 4500.
S27.S27_D33_F161_C1: Let's combine the C terms. We have 2C + C + C, which equals how many C?
S27.S27_D34_F162_C1: Perfect! Now we have 4C + 500 = 4500.
S27.S27_D35_F163_C1: To solve this, we subtract 500 from both sides.
S27.S27_D36_F164_C1: You would get 4C = 4000. Now divide by 4 on both sides.
S27.S27_D37_F165_C1: Excellent! We got C = 1000. Meaning the Caravan Master gets 1000 dirhams.
S27.S27_D38_F166_C1: Perfect! You now know how much to pay the Caravan Master.
S27.S27_D39_F167_C1: But we still need to know how much the Lead Merchant should get.
S27.S27_D40_F168_C1: We already know the formula L = C + 500, so, what is the value of L?
S27.S27_D41_F169_C2: L = 1000 + 500 = 1500 dirhams!
S27.S27_D42_F170_C1: Excellent! The Lead Merchant receives 1500 dirhams for his specialized knowledge.
S27.S27_D43_F171_C1: And how much should you get yourself, based on the formula M = 2C?
S27.S27_D44_F172_C2: M = 2 × 1000 = 2000 dirhams!
S27.S27_D45_F173_C1: Perfect! You receive the largest share for taking the greatest financial risk.
S27.S27_D46_F174_C1: Let's verify our solution. Does 2000 + 1500 + 1000 equal 4500?
S27.S27_D47_F175_C2: Yes! It adds up perfectly!
S27.S27_D48_F176_C1: This is the power of systematic mathematical thinking. What seemed impossible to solve by reasoning alone becomes clear through the method of Al Jabr.

S28.S28_D1_F177_C0: Al-Khwarizmi's revolutionary method of systematic problem-solving spreads from Baghdad's House of Wisdom to scholars across the known world.
S28.S28_D2_F178_C0: His gift to humanity is the art of finding unknown values through balanced equations he calls Al Jabr. This became the foundation of algebra, a mathematical language still spoken 1,200 years later.
S28.S28_D3_F179_C0: Those equations you are learning right now—they originated with him, in Baghdad, in the pursuit of transforming chaos into wisdom.

quest_completion.subheading: You've uncovered the Al-Khwarizmi's Merchant Mathematics Quest: From Chaos to Wisdom
quest_completion.content:
You completed the Baghdad Mathematics STEAMQuest!

  • •You organized chaos into clarity by categorizing business transactions and revealing hidden losses through systematic thinking
  • •You learned the balance principle using a physical scale to discover that mathematical equations follow the same rule—what you do to one side, you must do to the other
  • •You solved complex multi-sided problems by learning to isolate terms and handle equations with variables on both sides
  • •You transitioned from physical to abstract thinking by replacing real objects with mathematical symbols, making problem-solving faster and more powerful
  • •You optimized business profits using algebraic functions to discover that every local sale costs 6 dirhams in lost Damascus profits
  • •You learned to model uncertainty with absolute value equations and make risk-based decisions that balance mathematical optimization with practical wisdom

salaam_aleikum.definition: Salaam aleikum is a traditional Arabic greeting meaning "Peace be upon you," commonly used across the Islamic world as a respectful way to say hello.

with_the_moon.definition: In medieval times, "with the moon" meant "over time" or "from time to time," referring to how the moon changes phases. Here it means costs that vary depending on business activity.

al_jabr.definition: Al Jabr is Al-Khwarizmi's original Arabic term meaning "restoration" or "reunion of broken parts," which became the word "algebra" in modern mathematics.

dirham.definition: Dirham is a historical silver coin used as currency in the Islamic world during Al-Khwarizmi's time, serving as the standard unit of trade.

dirhams.definition: Dirhams are historical silver coins used as currency in the Islamic world during Al-Khwarizmi's time, serving as the standard unit of trade.

revenue.definition: Revenue is total money earned from business activities, representing all income flowing into a business from sales and services.

fixed_costs.definition: Fixed Costs are business expenses that remain constant regardless of production or sales volume, such as rent, salaries, and equipment costs.

variable_costs.definition: Variable Costs are business expenses that change in proportion to business activity levels, including materials, transportation, and commission fees.

ledger.definition: Ledger is a written record of all business transactions, showing money received and spent with descriptions of each entry.

x.definition: Variable (x) is a mathematical symbol representing an unknown quantity that we need to solve for in an equation.

equation.definition: Equation is a mathematical statement showing that two expressions are equal, with an equals sign acting like a balance scale.

equations.definition: Equations are mathematical statements showing that two expressions are equal, with an equals sign acting like a balance scale.

optimization.definition: Optimization is the process of finding the best possible solution or allocation of resources to maximize profit or minimize costs.

optimize.definition: Optimize is the process of finding the best possible solution or allocation of resources to maximize profit or minimize costs.

absolute.definition: Absolute Value is a mathematical concept showing the distance from zero, used to model uncertainty by indicating how far actual values can vary from predictions.

caravan.definition: Caravan is a group of merchants and animals traveling together along trade routes like the Silk Road for safety and mutual support.

caravans.definition: Caravans are groups of merchants and animals traveling together along trade routes like the Silk Road for safety and mutual support.

common.al-khwarizmi_description: A dignified older scholar with a neatly trimmed beard, wearing traditional robes and turban, carrying a small notebook and writing implements with a patient, wise expression.
common.tariq_description: A middle-aged date merchant with calloused hands, wearing practical trading clothes and carrying a coin pouch, with a concerned but eager-to-learn expression.
common.bg1_description: Bustling Baghdad marketplace with Islamic architecture, golden domes, palm trees, and merchants trading goods under colorful market stalls.
common.bg2_description: Interior of a traditional Baghdad bazaar with arched corridors, merchants selling dates and dried goods from sacks and pottery, warm golden lighting.
common.bg3_description: Outdoor date merchant quarter with clay buildings, woven baskets filled with dates, pottery vessels, and merchants in traditional robes conducting business under awnings.
common.bg4_description: Al-Khwarizmi's scholarly study with wooden bookshelves filled with scrolls, ornate Islamic arched windows, a balance scale and mathematical instruments on a wooden table.
common.bg5_description: Interior of Al-Khwarizmi's library study showing both scholars working together at a wooden table, surrounded by towering bookshelves and Islamic architectural details.
common.bg6_description: Grand interior of the House of Wisdom with Islamic arches, ornate columns, multiple scholarly workstations with books, scrolls, and mathematical instruments bathed in golden light.
common.bg7_description: Covered marketplace entrance with ornate Islamic arches, two robed figures walking toward the bustling outdoor bazaar, with camels and pottery visible under golden sunlight.
common.bg8_description: Grand exterior of the House of Wisdom at sunset with Islamic architecture, turquoise domes, two scholars walking across a vast courtyard plaza under dramatic golden skies.
common.bg9_description: Grand interior of the House of Wisdom with Islamic arches, ornate columns, multiple scholarly workstations with books, scrolls, and mathematical instruments bathed in golden light.
common.bg10_description: Islamic courtyard with ornate arches and turquoise columns, merchants and camels preparing for caravan departure, palm trees and golden sunset lighting.
common.bg11_description: Desert caravan scene with merchants and loaded camels traveling across golden sand dunes, palm trees, and a distant city silhouette under sunset skies.
common.bg12_description: Vast desert landscape with a camel caravan crossing rolling sand dunes, palm oases, and dramatic golden sunset lighting across the Silk Road trading route.
common.bg13_description: Dramatic desert scene with silhouetted camel caravan traveling through a sandstorm, golden atmospheric lighting creating an ethereal and dangerous desert environment.
common.bg14_description: Lone camel rider in foreground with caravan silhouettes in background, swirling desert sands and dramatic golden lighting creating an epic conclusion to the Silk Road journey.
common.bg15_description: Huge House of Wisdom library with multiple scholars working at research stations, towering bookshelves, ornate Islamic arches, and mathematical instruments throughout the grand hall.
common.bg16_description: Al-Khwarizmi working with an abacus in foreground while scholars gather in arched corridors of the House of Wisdom, golden lighting illuminating the mathematical learning environment.
common.bg17_description: Al-Khwarizmi teaching a diverse group of scholars in the House of Wisdom, standing at a table with books and instruments, surrounded by students from different cultures under ornate Islamic arches.
